html:
11.23.19  5:29 pm   11.22.19  7:17 pm   whoa no way! i have always heard that one as a waltz... just blew my own mind by listening to it in 12/8 (which was mostly successful with a conscious effort, i am pleased to report)

i think because the vocals so strongly imply a slower 3, i would have needed a 12/8 groove for a few bars before the verse, otherwise the count-in just gets recontextualised in my brain as "interesting weird rhythm"

      having said that i just tested it on my sister and she got the 12/8 straight away so maybe my brain is just weird. this makes me want to do a survey


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201911221917

11.22.19  7:17 pm   in might quit, when writing it, did you conceptualize it in 2 or in 3? because the entire song seems to have a 3:2 or 2:3 feel to it so i am keen to understand the process.

     it was immediately and always 4 quick groups of 3, with tempo around 102 bpm, each of those clicks having 3 subdivisions. can be written on paper as 12/8 or 4/4 with triplets, depending on whether you prefer to see a lot of dots or a lot of the number 3. even though i heard it clearly that way, i was aware that unfortunately 3x2 can get screwed and heard wrong if you're not very careful in how you portray the rhythms. did not want anyone to hear it as a 3/4 lullaby feel. did everything i could to ensure you hear it as a 4/4 or 12/8 west-african feel. the fact that you are not sure is actually a sign that i failed. tried to put solid clanks on the downbeats whenever possible, in addition to probably providing a firm count-off at the beginning

      in general when writing a song how does the time/feel factor into it?

     fully, entirely

      is it organic and known from the outset?

     yes

      does it come later?
original_html:
11.23.19  5:29 pm   11.22.19  7:17 pm   whoa no way! i have always heard that one as a waltz... just blew my own mind by listening to it in 12/8 (which was mostly successful with a conscious effort, i am pleased to report)

i think because the vocals so strongly imply a slower 3, i would have needed a 12/8 groove for a few bars before the verse, otherwise the count-in just gets recontextualised in my brain as "interesting weird rhythm"

      having said that i just tested it on my sister and she got the 12/8 straight away so maybe my brain is just weird. this makes me want to do a survey

11.22.19  7:17 pm   in might quit, when writing it, did you conceptualize it in 2 or in 3? because the entire song seems to have a 3:2 or 2:3 feel to it so i am keen to understand the process.

     it was immediately and always 4 quick groups of 3, with tempo around 102 bpm, each of those clicks having 3 subdivisions. can be written on paper as 12/8 or 4/4 with triplets, depending on whether you prefer to see a lot of dots or a lot of the number 3. even though i heard it clearly that way, i was aware that unfortunately 3x2 can get screwed and heard wrong if you're not very careful in how you portray the rhythms. did not want anyone to hear it as a 3/4 lullaby feel. did everything i could to ensure you hear it as a 4/4 or 12/8 west-african feel. the fact that you are not sure is actually a sign that i failed. tried to put solid clanks on the downbeats whenever possible, in addition to probably providing a firm count-off at the beginning

      in general when writing a song how does the time/feel factor into it?

     fully, entirely

      is it organic and known from the outset?

11.23.19  3:40 pm   11.22.19  12:27 pm My solutions to problems are always straight lines from problem to solution. However, sometimes certain parameters or obstacles mean that a straight line isn't viable. I can only see my straight line and seem to be blind to all the wiggly lines that appear plain to see for others. How do I see these other lines?


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201911221227

11.22.19  12:27 pm   How do I think outside the box? I tried not thinking about it but that didn't work. You seem to be rather good at it, or maybe your box is just larger
